title: Can logic be used to establish the 'truth' of any proposition if no other proposition is first accepted as 'true'? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. Logic can only be applied if you assume some proposition to be true. However, this is no different from any calculus. You can only find that the sum of two numbers is 5, for example, if you know what these two numbers are. You may think that this is in contrast with empirical knowledge. After all, I know there is a tree in my garden just by looking. Apparently, I don’t need to make any assumption or admit of anything prior to looking. And if I look, I will see the tree in my garden. Well, yes, but you will not know that this is a tree unless you had somehow learned to recognise that what you see is a tree. Empirical knowledge is essentially layers of logic so thick we cannot see through them and yet they are there. You will see a tree because of something very much like (A → B) ∧ A ⊢ B, only much, much more complicated. Thus, we know that (A → B) ∧ A ⊢ B is true without knowing what A and B stand for. We don’t need to. In fact, here, they don’t stand for anything at all. They are vacuous forms, and they form another form, here the form of the Modus ponens. (A → B) ∧ A ⊢ B, with in this metaphor, is the tree (and all logical formulas are trees). We all think we know what a tree is, and yet none of us actually knows what a tree is ultimately made of. How could we possibly know a tree if we don’t know what it is really made of? So, no, we don’t know what a tree is, we merely recognise trees, which only means that we are able to see that this thing I am looking at now is very similar to something else I have previously learned is a tree. So, I recognise trees without knowing what a tree is in reality. Thus, empirical knowledge works like logic: This thing is a tree if what I remember as a tree is really a tree. So, every second of our life, we have to assume our beliefs are true to be able to decide what we better do now, just to stay alive and comfortable. It works well enough for you if you are still reading this piece.

Can logic be used to establish the "truth" of any proposition if no other proposition is first accepted as "true"? Possibly not - but that’s my point, we can still muddle along admitting that even if we cannot be 100% certain of anything & still have pretty good grounds to assume all sorts of things are very probably true none the less. The advantage of always appreciating that we might be wrong about pretty much anything is that it keeps us vigilant with regard to any errors of judgement we may have made because we’re still open to hearing that there may be something we’ve missed of assumed. That’s what make science so powerful & allows it to error correct: because no scientific idea is ever ever ever considered ‘true’. If there’s independently verifiable evidence for it then it’s considered… ‘fact’? No! Never! It’s considered theory but not ‘theory’ in the conventional sense of the word like ‘guess’. It’s considered not shown to be wrong… yet - but it may be perhaps & that’s what keeps scientists vigilant because nothing is ever ever ever considered ‘true’ as such. Just probably true as far as we know. e.g. Newton’s Theory of Gravity, Darwin’s Theory of Evolution, Einstein’s Theory of Relativity etc. i.e. Science is certain of nothing & demands evidence of everything - however religion is certain of everything & demands evidence of nothing. - So which is more humble science or religion?

Question originally answered: Can logic be used to establish the "truth" of any proposition if no other proposition is first accepted as "true"?  Yes! Here’s a (very) simple example, where I do not accept any proposition at all as being true, not even any axioms, since this proof system has none: 1AssP2Reit[1]P3⟹I[1-2]P⟹P1AssP2Reit[1]P3⟹I[1-2]P⟹P This is a simple natural deduction proof that any proposition materially implies itself. Nowhere have I accepted the proposition PP to be true! I have merely shown that if I assume it to be true, that then it would of course be true. It is on line three of the proof that I discharge that assumption thereby making clear that I will not actually be accepting it to be true at all, and was merely examining the consequences of hypothetically assuming it to be true. However, the conclusion drawn on line three is a proposition of which the truth has hereby been established.

Absolutely not, and as the question implies this fact has extremely important consequences. In fact, consequences are the point. All logics are consequential. In every case conditional statements can be made - ‘if this then that’. What the nature of this and that are may be indeterminate in some sense (consider fuzzy logic) but in no way does that make the consequence invalid or unconditional.  The factoring ‘0.35’, for example must be ironically be 100% true or else the algorithm is inoperable. Where conditions are not certain then nothing follows. Precedents must be set in stone just like the past is no longer the present and will not be altered. So, at some essential level there must always be truths accepted as absolute for any logic to operate. These ‘truths by default’ are given a name derived from the Greek axios - ‘worthy’. They are called ‘axioms’. Without them there is no possible argument.

From what I understand, there must first be established AXIOMS. But axioms are “UNIVERSAL PROPOSITIONAL STATEMENTS” that is, a “HYPOTHESIS” or “THEORY” does not mean that it is “true.” However, it can still be logical. The process of logic is valid, but that does not mean that what is accepted is actually true. The premise is “given.” BUT IF the GIVEN premise is actually TRUE, the process of valid logic will work to form true statements. i.e. categorical syllogisms, sorites, etc. Two books about this particular question, I think, that would really help understand this point and the questions, are: An Introduction to Logic and Scientific Method by Morris R. Cohen and Ernest Nagel and Introduction To Logic by Irving M Copi.

Can logic be used to establish the "truth" of any proposition if no other proposition is first accepted as "true"? Only if the proposition to be established is a necessary truth, which means that its denial would constitute or entail a contradiction. The truth of any other proposition must be demonstrated by inferring it from other propositions, and those other propositions must be inferred from still others, and so on indefinitely. At some point, you reach a set of propositions that you just accept without proof. We call them by various names depending on context — assumptions, axioms, postulates, presuppositions, self-evident truths, etc. — but whatever they’re called, we can do no reasoning without them.

Can logic be used to establish the "truth" of any proposition if no other proposition is first accepted as "true"? Yes. In any given mathematical system there exists an axiomatic basis. The theorems derived from that axiomatic basis in that mathematical system are proven true by necessity where the axioms hold true In this case we have not proven the axioms. Moreover, we do not even need to “accept” the axioms as true. The axioms can be true, false, or some other indeterminate state. However, what we have proven is the logical relation between the axiom and the theorem. For a simple example, consider the following axiom from Euclid: First Axiom: Things which are equal to the same thing are also equal to one another. Let’s walk through a simple logical experiment: Let us call this single-axiom basis AALet XX note a thingLet Y=XY=XLet Z=XZ=XWe can conclude that axiomatic basis A→Y=ZA→Y=ZGiven this setup, we can conclude the following: We have NOT demonstrated axiomatic basis AA contains only truthful statementsWe have NOT demonstrated that Y=ZY=Z is a truthful statement derived only from truthful predicatesHowever, we HAVE demonstrated that A→Y=ZA→Y=Z is a truthful logical relation, and we have done so without accepting axioms prior to this demonstration

“Can logic be used to establish the "truth" of any proposition if no other proposition is first accepted as "true"?” I’ll assume “other” in “no other proposition” means “apart from the axioms of logic”. The answer is yes formally but no if you mean content-loaded propositions Lots of logical propositions can be proved from only the axioms of logic. A simple example should illustrate the idea. In some formulations of logic, there is the axiom A and B => B and A. It is easy to prove the following extension: A and B and C => C and B and A. But no real content-loaded proposition can be proved without specific axioms.

No. You have to have some “true” propositions (called the “axioms”) to start with. Logic is about how truth is preserved in inference, but you have to start with some truths to be preserved. Every rule of logic takes the form of “if these things are true, then those things can be inferred”. If you assume that there’s a proposition that’s been “proved”, then that proposition must be at the end of some chain of these inferences—it’s that chain that constitutes the “proof”. But if there’s no axioms accepted as true without proof, then the chain cannot have a beginning.

Let us define terms. There is Analytic Logic, developed by Aristotle and there is Synthetic Logic developed by Kant. Most scholars know next to nothing about Kant's Logic, so I will presume the question is about Analytic Logic. Analytic Logic requires *premises* to be stated *first* before arriving at a Conclusion, verified by the procedure of Analytic Logic. For only one of countless examples, in the science of Biology, the biologist *presumes* the existence of Flora, and then begins to *analyze* the vast variety of Flora in the world. That is, the existence of Flora must first be given before Analytic Logic can take a single step.

No. Des Cartes famous “ I think, therefore I am" is an implicit axiom/postulate. It postulates that he is real, and not something imagined in someone else's mind. “Truth” in a logical system is just what can derived from assumed axioms by the rules of formal deductive logic. Now, this formal method has gotten us a long ways, but certainly has its limits. Goedel's theorem showed that for a relatively simple system which has a finite set of axioms , either there are statements which cannot be labeled as true or false ( the system is incomplete) or there are statements which can be shown to be both true and false ( the system is inconsistent).

Yes, the truths that can be proven without any assumptions are known as validities. They are statements that hold in all models of the terms used. All statements that have “content”, in a certain sense of “content”, require premises that also have content. But validities can be interesting. The deduction theorem says that being able to prove a statement QQ from premises P1,…,PnP1,…,Pn is equivalent to being able to prove (P1∧…∧Pn)→Q(P1∧…∧Pn)→Q without any premises.

No. Logic divides what is existing and that is truth. Establishment is a belief that one want to exist but it is not truth. Same is with acceptance. That which does not need acceptance, proposition and belief is truth.
No. “Proof” is always relative to premises that are assumed “for the sake of argument”. Without “other propositions” accepted as true there is nothing upon which to base a logical proof.
There are logical truisms, such as “A or not A”. This will be a true statement for any properly constructed proposition A, whether A is true or false.
